perturbation.original_text: Each driver will have a set amount of time (e.g. 10 seconds) to accept or reject the order, or the order will automatically be rejected by time and the lack of response will be recorded for future reference/internal driver ranking in the future.
perturbation.changed_text: Each driver will have a set amount of time (e.g. 2 seconds) to accept or reject the order, or the order will automatically be rejected by time and the lack of response will be recorded for future reference/internal driver ranking in the future.
perturbation.explanation: Limiting the driver's response time to 2 seconds may create an unsafe working condition for drivers who may be driving when an order is received. This may violate Washington state labor laws related to safety and reasonable working conditions.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Washington State Labor Laws related to safety and reasonable working conditions

perturbation.original_text: Milestone #1 -January 1st, 2019 Milestone #2- February 1st, 2019. Milestone #3 - March 1st, 2019. Milestone #4 - April 1st, 2019.
perturbation.changed_text: Milestone #1 -December 1st, 2018 Milestone #2- January 1st, 2019. Milestone #3 - February 1st, 2019. Milestone #4 - March 1st, 2019.
perturbation.explanation: If the agreement was signed in February 11th, 2020, mandating completion of milestones that are in the past, specifically December 1st, 2018 and January 1st, 2019, is clearly inconsistent and would not be legally enforceable. This contradicts fundamental contract law principles of feasibility and mutual agreement. The client is being binded to completing tasks before the contract was written.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract law principles of feasibility and mutual agreement.

perturbation.original_text: o Driver will scan the customers ID using the Trulioo API right before they handle the delivery to the customer. After this last ID check, the transaction will be completed.
perturbation.changed_text: o The driver may, at their discretion, request to see the customer's ID before completing the delivery. The transaction will be considered completed regardless of whether ID verification occurs.
perturbation.explanation: Washington state law requires verification of age for cannabis delivery. Removing the mandatory ID check directly contradicts state regulations regarding the sale and delivery of cannabis, potentially leading to fines or legal repercussions for both the delivery service and the driver.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Washington State cannabis regulations regarding age verification for delivery.
